plot.topic: Everything you should know about building and running a micro SaaS

chapters.chapter_title: What Micro SaaS Actually Is (and Is Not)
chapters.chapter_summary: Defines micro SaaS as a capital-efficient, narrow-scope software business optimized for profitability, control, and sustainability rather than venture-scale outcomes.
chapters.include: bootstrapping vs venture scale, founder leverage, small teams or solo founders, revenue ceilings, lifestyle vs ambition tradeoffs
chapters.avoid: romanticized indie hacking, overnight success stories, vague entrepreneurship slogans

chapters.chapter_summary: Explains why micro SaaS lives or dies by precise problem selection, focusing on painful, recurring, narrowly scoped problems with clear buyers.
chapters.include: job-to-be-done framing, willingness to pay, niche markets, B2B bias, frequency and severity of pain
chapters.avoid: broad consumer ideas, TAM obsession, idea-first thinking
chapters.backreferences: What Micro SaaS Actually Is (and Is Not)

chapters.chapter_title: Product Scope, Simplicity, and Technical Leverage
chapters.chapter_summary: Covers how successful micro SaaS products deliberately constrain scope while maximizing leverage through automation, APIs, and boring technology.
chapters.include: single-core feature focus, integration-first products, technical debt triage, build vs buy decisions, maintenance cost awareness
chapters.avoid: overengineering, premature scalability, novelty-driven tech stacks

chapters.chapter_title: Pricing, Revenue Models, and Cash Discipline
chapters.chapter_summary: Analyzes pricing as the primary growth lever in micro SaaS, emphasizing simple models, early monetization, and ruthless cash-flow awareness.
chapters.include: subscription pricing, value-based pricing, annual plans, churn math, runway without funding
chapters.avoid: free-first strategies, ad-based models, vanity metrics
chapters.backreferences: Product Scope, Simplicity, and Technical Leverage

chapters.chapter_summary: Breaks down why distribution is the real bottleneck in micro SaaS and how credibility, trust, and narrow channels outperform scale tactics.
chapters.include: founder-led sales, content as proof of competence, niche communities, SEO patience, outbound realism
chapters.avoid: growth hacks, viral fantasies, generic social media posting
chapters.backreferences: Pricing, Revenue Models, and Cash Discipline

chapters.chapter_title: Operations, Longevity, and When to Quit
chapters.chapter_summary: Explores the long-term reality of running micro SaaS, including maintenance, customer support, opportunity cost, and rational shutdown decisions.
chapters.include: support load management, churn diagnosis, compounding improvements, kill criteria, portfolio thinking
chapters.avoid: founder burnout glorification, sunk-cost fallacy, emotional attachment to ideas
